docs.lead_paragraph: Caroline Rose Hunt, the 81-year-old oil heiress who built a second fortune in hotels and resorts, has long supported the United Way, lavishing millions on it and persuading her wealthy friends to do the same. Now, she has joined groups of other elderly, wealthy donors who have allowed insurance companies, hedge funds and other investors to insure their lives in exchange for a promise that part the death benefits will flow to the donors' favorite charities.

headline.main: Charities Look to Benefit From a New Twist on Life Insurance

docs.abstract: Some elderly, wealthy donors are allowing insurance companies, hedge funds and other investors to insure their lives in exchange for promise that part of death benefits will go to donors' favorite charities; oil heiress Caroline Rose Hunt is taking part in four such pools, allowing unknown investors to insure her life for $70 million; laws in most states still prohibit such plans, although laws are changing; Nashville, Tenn, life insurance broker Edward H Netherland has developed more complex plan known as Life Insurance and Life Annuities Based Certificates (Lilacs); Hunt photo (M)
docs.snippet: Caroline Rose Hunt, the 81-year-old oil heiress who built a second fortune in hotels and resorts, has long supported the United Way, lavishing millions on it and persuading her wealthy friends to do the same.    Now, she has joined groups of other...

docs.lead_paragraph: Health care inflation may remain in the single-digit range for another year, according to a new survey of managed care prices, a report that employers and insurers watch closely for early indications of next year's health costs. Some experts said that the survey, reported yesterday by the consulting firm Hewitt Associates, would ease pressure on consumers who had been pushed hard to pay more of their own health care costs.

headline.main: '05 H.M.O. Price Increases Estimated in Single Digits

docs.abstract: Hewitt Associates survey suggests that health care inflation may remain in single-digit range for another year; health maintenance organizations are seeking 13.7 percent increases from large employers, on average, for 2005 coverage, but Hewitt and several Wall Street health care analysts say those will be pushed down to 10 percent or lower as employers bargain with insurers over next few months (M)
docs.snippet: Health care inflation may remain in the single-digit range for another year, according to a new survey of managed care prices, a report that employers and insurers watch closely for early indications of next year's health costs.       Some experts...

docs.lead_paragraph: Ask people here why Las Vegas is the nation's fastest-growing city, and they point to the thriving casino industry and to its ever-growing appetite for workers. But there is another, little understood force contributing to the allure of Las Vegas, a force often viewed as the casino industry's archnemesis. It is Culinary Local 226, also called the Culinary, the city's largest labor union, an unusual -- and unusually successful -- union that has done a spectacular job catapulting thousands of dishwashers, hotel maids and other unskilled workers into the middle class.

headline.main: Local 226, 'the Culinary,' Makes Las Vegas the Land of the Living Wage

docs.abstract: Culinary Local 226 in Las Vegas has done spectacular job of catapulting its 48,000 hotel and restaurant workers in casino industry, 65 percent of them nonwhite and 70 percent female, into middle class homeowners with some of highest wages in service industry and comprehensive health insurance coverage; photo; 24 casinos help finance Culinary Training Academy that trains workers to step up to higher-paying jobs (M)
docs.snippet: Ask people here why Las Vegas is the nation's fastest-growing city, and they point to the thriving casino industry and to its ever-growing appetite for workers.    But there is another, little understood force contributing to the allure of Las Vegas,...

docs.lead_paragraph: Here are a few of the startling, improbable, only-in-Vegas apparitions that can be seen in and around Las Vegas Boulevard South, also known as the Strip: an ersatz Eiffel Tower. A Venetian palace. A miniature Brooklyn Bridge. An Egyptian pyramid that, once darkness falls, sends a towering shaft of light into the black desert sky. Here is another: a petite woman with a jet-black ponytail driving to and from the pyramid in a white Dodge Ram pickup.

headline.main: Crossing the Border Into the Middle Class

docs.abstract: Fifth article in series American Dreamers: The Lure of Las Vegas relates Graciela Diaz's rise from illegal Mexican migrant to wife, mother and middle-class homeowner who earns $40,000 a year as unionized waitress in Luxor hotel; former seamstress, who met husband in Los Angeles sweatshop, has thrived in booming economy of gambling mecca, advancing herself from busing tables by attending Las Vegas Culinary Training Academy, co-sponsored by union and hotel-casino industry (M)
docs.snippet: Here are a few of the startling, improbable, only-in-Vegas apparitions that can be seen in and around Las Vegas Boulevard South, also known as the Strip: an ersatz Eiffel Tower. A Venetian palace. A miniature Brooklyn Bridge. An Egyptian pyramid...

docs.lead_paragraph: Bush Contacts Lawyer About Inquiry Into Leak President Bush has contacted a private lawyer about representing him in a grand jury investigation into the disclosure of a C.I.A. undercover officer's identity, the White House said. The move surprised law enforcement officials and political figures. While some White House advisers have been the focus of speculation, Mr. Bush has not been seen as a potential target of the inquiry. PAGE A24 AMERICAN DREAMERS The Lure of Las Vegas Thanks to a relentlessly booming economy and an unusual collaboration between labor and industry, Las Vegas has become a paradise for unskilled newcomers, many of them immigrants. In Las Vegas, unlike most other American cities, dishwashers, busboys, hotel housekeepers and hotel janitors can easily gain a foothold in the middle class.

docs.section_name: Front Page; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate on Wednesday gave the White House $25 billion for operations in Afghanistan and Iraq but joined the House in putting new controls on the money despite administration requests for substantial freedom in how to use it. On a 95-to-0 vote, senators agreed to add the money to a broad Pentagon spending plan, bringing the total cost of the legislation to more than $447 billion. Even Democrats who have raised objections to administration policy in Iraq did not oppose the spending, saying they viewed it as a necessity for troops in need of new armor and other vital equipment.

headline.main: With Some Strings Attached, Senate Approves War Money

docs.abstract: Senate, 95-0, gives White House $25 billion for operations in Iraq and Afghanistan but joins House in putting new controls on money; Democrats go along, to support troops; Senate sets $22.5 billion for specific Pentagon accounts and $2.5 billion for Bush administration to use as it sees fit, although not until defense secretary consults with senior members of both parties and provides prior written request; Sen John McCain says Congress should still push for war money to go through normal channels; Senate also votes, 70-25, to open military health care coverage to members of National Guard and Reserves; Sen Lindsay Graham notes they constitute about forty percent of troops in Iraq and Afghanistan; his photo (M)
docs.snippet: The Senate on Wednesday gave the White House $25 billion for operations in Afghanistan and Iraq but joined the House in putting new controls on the money despite administration requests for substantial freedom in how to use it.    On a 95-to-0 vote,...

docs.lead_paragraph: Only a year after it opened in 2001, the 25-story, 453-room Kalia Tower at the Hilton Hawaiian Village in Waikiki was shut because of a persistent mold problem. The tower cost $95 million to build, and the Hilton Hotels Corporation spent $55 million on the cleanup, which lasted 13 months. Hilton has sued two dozen companies and individuals, including architects, construction companies and engineers, saying they were responsible for construction defects that allowed the gray fungus to flourish. Cases like Hilton's have captured the attention of the commercial real estate industry. Lenders are trying to develop new approaches and policies for guarding against mold, microscopic organisms that have been known to cause allergic reactions in some people and that can seriously reduce a building's value. Fitch Ratings has warned lenders in large transactions to make sure that inspectors test for mold because of the potential risk for income-producing property.

headline.main: High-Rise Alert: There's a Fungus Among Us

docs.abstract: Lenders are trying to develop new approaches and policies for guarding against mold in commercial properties that can reduce buildings' value; Insurance Industry Institute economist Robert J Hartwig says insured losses in recent years for mold damage have risen from $700 million in 2000 to $3 billion in 2002; insurance companies, fearing mold could be new asbestos in terms of litigation, no longer cover mold damage in conventional policies; persistent mold problem at Hilton Hawaiian Village in Waikiki noted; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Only a year after it opened in 2001, the 25-story, 453-room Kalia Tower at the Hilton Hawaiian Village in Waikiki was shut because of a persistent mold problem. The tower cost $95 million to build, and the Hilton Hotels Corporation spent $55 million...

docs.lead_paragraph: FROM the low, flat plain on the Bronx side of the Harlem River, John F. Kennedy High School rises as abruptly as a canyon wall. Its eight stories contain more than 4,200 students, well beyond official capacity, and the academic record could be charitably described as middling. Kennedy, then, is exactly the sort of massive school viewed with disfavor by Mayor Bloomberg and his Department of Education. On the ground floor of Kennedy, tucked between the football field and the weight room, a teacher named Manny Martinez runs an automotive technology program. In the combined garage and classroom, amid tool cabinets and hydraulic lifts and service bays, about 170 pupils a year study a '97 Grand Am and '96 Cavalier the way medical school students study cadavers, as a means of learning anatomy and organ function.

headline.main: As Cars Become More Intricate, Automotive Tech Class Is Junked

docs.abstract: Samuel G Freedman On Education column discusses plans to end program at John F Kennedy High School (NYC) that teaches students automotive technology; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The new Medicare drug discount cards are sowing so much confusion that it makes us wonder whether they will prove successful. The Bush administration needs to reach out more aggressively to help elderly Americans -- especially those who are poor -- understand the available choices and help them sign up. Thus far, neither the government nor the private sector has done an adequate job. The discount cards are a stopgap measure intended to help Medicare participants until the full prescription drug benefit kicks in on Jan. 1, 2006. More than 70 different national and regional cards have been approved by the federal government, each offering somewhat different choices of drugs to those who enroll and fees that range from nothing at all to $30 a year.
docs.abstract: Editorial on confusion about new Medicare drug discount cards; urges Bush administration to reach out more aggressively to help elderly Americans understand options and sign up; notes program offers those with computer access ability to compare prices across wide range of cards but that many elderly are not comfortable with computers
docs.snippet: The new Medicare drug discount cards are sowing so much confusion that it makes us wonder whether they will prove successful. The Bush administration needs to reach out more aggressively to help elderly Americans -- especially those who are poor --...

docs.lead_paragraph: The HealthSouth Corporation said yesterday that it had finished an internal review that verified years of fraud worth $3.4 billion at the rehabilitation company. But even as the report provided more evidence of the amount of fraud at HealthSouth, a federal judge rejected a five-year prison sentence for a former HealthSouth executive, Kenneth Livesay, and instead sentenced him yesterday to six months of home confinement. The judge, U.W. Clemon of United States District Court, also sentenced Mr. Livesay to five years of probation, ordered him to forfeit $750,000 and said he must pay a $10,000 fine.
docs.abstract: HealthSouth Corp finishes internal review that verifies years of fraud worth $3.4 billion; Judge U W Clemon rejects five-year prison sentence for former executive Kenneth Livesay and instead sentences him to six months of home confinement and five years of probation; orders him to forefeit $750,000 and pay $10,000 fine (S)
